newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine two-year note coupon falls to 11.25 pct.
newsitem.headline: Philippine two-year note coupon falls to 11.25 pct.

text.p: The coupon rate on the Philippines' two-year fixed rate Treasury notes fell to 11.25 percent in the monthly auction from 11.875 percent in February, the Bureau of Treasury said on Tuesday.
The average rate likewise fell to 11.082 from 11.775 percent. Rates moved from 10.625 to 11.25 percent.
The auction had 5.86 billion pesos worth of bids, of which four billion pesos were awarded.
Traders said the slide in the two-year notes were instigated by the plunge in Treasury bill rates in Monday's auction.
This prompted the Philippine Central Bank to trim its overnight borrowing and lending rates by 0.1875 percentage point each to 10.25 and 12.75 percent, respectively.
There could have even been a steeper drop in the two-year coupon rate if the Central Bank's rate cuts were deeper, a dealer said.
However, "banks are beginning to get a little wary on the trend in rates," a big bank dealer said.
"A lot of them held off first," he said, since the Central Bank had not dropped its overnight rates significantly and may raise rates if there is peso speculation.
